nodes.bodyText:
This sequence is executed very very early. Is TR::Compiler->target already set at this point?
Also, there is no value in having this as a static because the code is executed exactly once.
Actually the TR_J9VMBase::getPPCProcessorType(); needs to be put back as that's actually the initialization for the old api's. We will have to keep them in for now.

Is there another PR that needs to be delivered first for this issue to be solved?
If not, what happens if we deliver this PR in this form?

Good eye, more work is needed here.
The problem here was that id() was not initialized at this point, and it will break my test if I switch to the new api over here so I reverted back to use the old api. However what I've done here is incorrect.
I should set the id() with TR_J9VMBase::getPPCProcessorType() that way I could use my new api here without breaking my test(the check between old api and new api)
Does this work correctly? You seem to be setting the TR_Processor returned by id(), but then using the Port library's processor enum to perform the check...

Inside TR::Compiler->target.cpu.is(OMR_PROCESSOR_PPC_P6), we have tests that verifies the correctness of new api's against old api. In order for this to work here, we need to set id() for the old APIs.

This (and the other checks like it) look like they've always been incorrect to me. It looks like we should be checking whether we're at least POWER8 to use the mtvsr* instructions instead of whether we're exactly POWER8.
@zl-wang Do you know if this was intentional?

i saw that too. And, it should be >= p8.
maybe a new issue is more appropriate.
Opened #9698 to track this.
It's minor, just curious why we need to say (!customP4 || (customP4 && ...)) ?
The customP4 && is not necessary, i'll get rid of it.

better not to touch these portion of code.  i have a waiting commit to be merged for reworking trampolines etc for POWER10.
that customP4 is actually meaningful for POWER4 machines (there was a performance bug in hardware for countCache prediction ... that customP4 was to work around that bug).

Are you suggesting to leave the change in as it is?
I'm turning it into
if( (helper & 0x80000000) && (!customP4 || TR::comp()->target().cpu.is(OMR_PROCESSOR_PPC_GP)))
which should be equivalent.
I thought you are trying to throw away customP4 all together. In case, something wrong is unnecessarily committed.  Fine, that equiv transformation alone looks ok.

The same as above re checking customP4 twice. Also, not sure the transformation is equivalent. If customP4 == false, proc = TR_DefaultPPCProcessor, which is not the same as TR_PPCgp. Which means the if() will not be true.
Good eye. I think we need to get rid of the !customP4 over here.
changing to if ( (dispatcher & 0x80000000) && ((customP4 && TR::comp()->target().cpu.is(OMR_PROCESSOR_PPC_GP)))
@zl-wang could you please take a quick look to see if the code behaves as expected?
there was some code to be improved, but it is not in the scope of this PR.  equiv transformations look fine to me at a quick glimpse.
Why did we delete all other similar style methods but left this one?
There are four instances of getPPCSupportsVSX() in closedj9. To make sure I don't break the build I'm temporarily keeping this in until we switch closedj9 to use the new APIs.

Just trying to understand: why would supportsFeature be removed if you introduced calls to it in this PR?
Also, if supports_feature_test is only used within this class, can we make it private?

The end goal is to have every single platform use the bool OMR::CPU::supportsFeature(uint32_t feature) API.
Currently we want to make sure that the new APIs are getting called correctly by comparing their query results to the old APIs. I added the tests in bool J9::CPU::Power::supportsFeature() and bool J9::CPU::Power::isAtLeast(). bool J9::CPU::Power::supportsFeature() will override bool OMR::CPU::supportsFeature(uint32_t feature) for now. Once we no longer need the test then these overrides can be removed and we will fall back to use the bool OMR::CPU::supportsFeature(uint32_t feature) API.
Yes I can make supports_feature_test private.
